channel.title: Is there a way to calculate RuneScape Exp with an algorithm? [Solved]
channel.description:
Edit: I need a LevelToExp convert function. There is a ConvertXpToLvl function in srl, but I'm not sure how to rewrite that to give me the exp when I put in the Level. :(
Is there a way to calculate RuneScape Exp with an algorithm?
This would really help since I made this huge fuckin array with 101 values lol. (lvl 1 = 0 exp, to maxed out = 200,000,00 exp)
Thanks :)
~Ron

item.title: Is there a way to calculate RuneScape Exp with an algorithm? [Solved]
item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

I see what you’re saying. What I wanted was the minimum amount of exp for a certain lvl. Like the minimum exp for lvl 2 would be 83. Minimum exp for lvl 3 would be 174, and so on.

item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote=“Ron, post:20, topic:41262”]I don’t know how it works, but it’s taken off of the ConvertXpToLvl function. I wonder how they figured it out. Any way, I checked all the values using the table Weibs provided and all the values worked. I even figured out total exp needed for lvl 101, 102, and 103. You can keep going but max is 200 mil exp.

http://www.tip.it/runescape/?page=xp_table.htm[/quote]

I mean based on a level, just a level you can’t get the exact current xp, I mean it’s nice without 100 lines of cases and maybe 10 lines of a backwards equation but I don’t see how it’s possible to get the exact xp of a level, unless I’m just confused on what it’s supposed to do and what you want it to do.

item.source: Is there a way to calculate RuneScape Exp with an algorithm? [Solved]

item.title: Is there a way to calculate RuneScape Exp with an algorithm? [Solved]
item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

I figured it out. Here is the reverse of it. I posted this on villu, hopefully someone other than me will find it useful.

Function code:

function ConvertLvlToXp(Level : Integer) : integer;
var
  i, exp, diff : integer;
begin
  for i := 1 to Level do
  begin
    diff := Trunc(i + 300 * Pow(2, i / 7));
    exp := exp + diff;
  end;
  result := exp/4;
end;

Test code:

program New;

var
  i : integer;

{*******************************************************************************
function ConvertLvlToXp(Xp: Integer): Integer;
By: Ron
Description: Returns exp based on level
*******************************************************************************}
function ConvertLvlToXp(Level : Integer) : integer;
var
  i, exp, diff : integer;
begin
  for i := 1 to Level-1 do
  begin
    diff := Trunc((i) + 300 * Pow(2, (i) / 7));
    exp := exp + diff;
  end;
  result := exp/4;
end;

begin
  ClearDebug;
  for i := 1 to 100 do
  begin
    WriteLn('Level '+IntToStr(i)+': '+IntToStr(ConvertLvlToXp(i)));
  end;
end.

~Ron

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

Naw Weibs, that’s what I did in the first place. I made a huge array, 101 values, for lvls 1, to 101 (there is a lvl 100, and what I consider lvl 101 is the max exp which is 200 m).

That takes about 10 msc, but just incase if I ever fuck that exp array up or someone using my script accidently changes a value and forgets, the easiest way to prevent that would be to create an equation that did it altogether and then set each value from that equation into an array.

Now I’m sure there is a way, since SRL has ConvertExpToLvl function. Though, I don’t know how to make it so it converts LvlToExp, which is what I need.

item.title: Is there a way to calculate RuneScape Exp with an algorithm? [Solved]
item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

[quote=“Cheesehunk, post:8, topic:41262”]Do you mean like this? (From SRL)

function ConvertXpToLvl(xp: Integer): Integer; var level, diff, exp: Integer; begin for level := 1 to 99 do begin z diff := Trunc(level + 300 * Pow(2, level / 7)); exp := exp + diff; if ((exp / 4) > xp) then begin Result := level; Exit; end; end; Result := 99; end;

EDIT: Brak and Flyboy made it if you wanted to know.[/quote]

How would I make it so I can convert the Level To Exp?

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Cheesehunk Cheesehunk
item.description:
@Cheesehunk wrote:

Do you mean like this? (From SRL)

function ConvertXpToLvl(xp: Integer): Integer; var level, diff, exp: Integer; begin for level := 1 to 99 do begin z diff := Trunc(level + 300 * Pow(2, level / 7)); exp := exp + diff; if ((exp / 4) > xp) then begin Result := level; Exit; end; end; Result := 99; end;

EDIT: Brak and Flyboy made it if you wanted to know.

item.source: Is there a way to calculate RuneScape Exp with an algorithm? [Solved]

item.title: Is there a way to calculate RuneScape Exp with an algorithm? [Solved]
item.dc:creator: @Aftermath_961 Aftermath
item.description:
@Aftermath_961 wrote:

Here’s a formula I made.
y = 5.16071 x^2 + 66.075x + -70.7
Where x is the level, and y is the experience.

If you prefer the other way, it’s the inverse.
y = -0.00000479074 x^2 + 0.0121784x + 1.0114
Where x is the experience, and y is the level.

It’s pretty accurate, and if it’s not an integer, it’s floor’d or ceil’d.
If it’s over or equal to .5, it rounds up, otherwise down.

Enjoy. This is only taking into consideration the points
(1, 0), (2, 83), (3, 174), (4, 276), (5, 388), (6, 512)

[hr]

This one might actually be closer:
y = 0.157407 x^3 + 3.50794 x^2 + 71.0648x + -74.6667
Where x is the level, and y is the experience.

y = 3.3355e-9 x^3 + -0.0000073522 x^2 + 0.0126567x + 0.999725
Where x is the experience, and y is the level.

Read full topic

item.title: Is there a way to calculate RuneScape Exp with an algorithm? [Solved]
item.dc:creator: @Ron Ron
item.description:
@Ron wrote:

no

An algorithm (math equation) that will calculate the total exp to achieve the next lvl. Such as this…

83 exp to reach lvl 2
174 exp to reach lvl 3
276 exp to reach lvl 4
388 exp to reach lvl 5
512 exp to reach lvl 6

so some kind of math equation where if I plugged in 1 for x, I would get 0, if I plugged in 2, I should get 83, if I plugged in 6 I should get 512.

A math equation to compute this. There must be one.

Read full topic
